content.intro:
Canals and museums, terraces and tulips… Amsterdam, so familiar and yet so different, is the city of possibilities. Discover its rich past, taste its exciting present.

Amsterdam is a city that reveals itself little by little. A city of contrasts as well: wealthy and poor, traditional and innovative, conservative and tolerant, of modest size with a global reputation. For those discovering it for the first time, Amsterdam is a labyrinth surrounded by canals bordered by stately old houses, a heritage of the Dutch Golden Age. By day, don't hesitate to lose yourself, on foot or by bicycle, in the maze of narrow streets. Stop to admire the tiny bridges straddling the canals, the shady terraces and the flowerboxes in the windows. It's here, far from the bustle of the centre, that you best feel the freshness, which seems to float over the city like the skies in Vermeer's landscapes. Here, quiet, tree-lined streets; further away, a tiny square where benches await a short break during your wanderings; nearby, a welcoming bar.
Amsterdam is a cosmopolitan city. It's to be expected: the variety of faces corresponds with the variety of restaurants. You will be seduced by a ‘brown café' on one corner and by a candlelit gourmet dinner on another. Besides the quintessential tulips, the markets overflow with vegetables and exotic fruits. If your appetite is for culture as well, the Van Gogh, NEMO, Rijksmuseum, and Stedelijk museums offer innumerable treasures. There are also trendy galleries representing young artists, chic hotels, antiques dealers, and much more to discover. In fact, a few days may not be enough time to see all there is to see… All the better for a return visit, because Amsterdam always has more to surprise you.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Amsterdam

content.title: Unique arty experience at Hotel Not Hotel

introduction.small: Amidst Oud-West Amsterdam's trendy boutiques and coffee shops and the nearby Foodhallen market, Hotel Not Hotel stands out with unusual accommodation concepts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Unique arty experience at Hotel Not Hotel

paragraphs.text:
Its name tells it all: Hotel Not Hotel is not a hotel, or shall we say, probably not the kind you are used to stay at. Lovers of the unexpected will crave this unique experience. In the exhibition area of the huge lobby, an authentic tram car seems to have been abandoned next to a couch, and a light-blue Volkswagen minivan is parked on the mezzanine. And yet, make no mistake, even if they are part of the decoration, they are also and most importantly… bedrooms! You will find many other such curiosities, hidden behind bookshelves that open just like in a spy movie, or nestled on a platform up in the air, or through a green wall… One of them has even been drawn like a Spanish villa! Each of the 23 rooms tells a particular story, conceived by totally unhampered designers. And yet, despite this super trendy aspect, Hotel Not Hotel remains affordable to anyone, especially considering it is located in the historic neighbourhood of Oud-West Amsterdam.

Hotel Not Hotel
Piri Reïsplein 34
1057 KH Amsterdam

+31 20 820 4538

https://www.hotelnothotel.com/

Rooms: from 35 EUR

content.title: 360° view at the Blue Amsterdam Café

introduction.small: Blue Amsterdam Café almost feels like the rooftop of Europe. Let yourself go and enjoy the amazing view along with delicious coffee.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 360° view at the Blue Amsterdam Café

paragraphs.text:
Between bike rides, craft beer and traditional dishes like the broodje Haring (small herring sandwiches), Amsterdam brims with various activities and possibilities, more thrilling than the next. In the southern part of the old town, you only need to reach the Kalverpassage, not far from the flower market, to live one of those moments you will remember for a long time: climb up a mall and discover a gorgeous location where light is the key. Up there, enjoy a 360° breathtaking view over the roofs of Amsterdam. Some even say the view of the skyline is the best of the whole capital.

From a food point of view, Blue Amsterdam Café will fill all your needs: cocktails, homemade burgers, salads… Take your pick on the menu and enjoy affordable pricing too. There is something for every taste, whether you are vegan, vegetarian or even flexitarian. Friendly service and warm atmosphere top it all. The decor is set for you to bask under the soft Dutch sun, or gaze at the rain falling from the clouds. Whichever will have you in awe.

Blue Amsterdam Café
Winkelcentrum Kalverpassage
Singel 457
1012 WP Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 427 3901

www.blue-amsterdam.nl/en/

Menu: around 18 EUR

content.title: Graffiti from around the world at the Street art museum

introduction.small: In Amsterdam's Nieuw-West district, amidst formerly abandoned warehouses, street art finally gets its own museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Graffiti from around the world at the Street art museum

paragraphs.text:
Located in the north of Amsterdam and nestled in a huge warehouse formerly used in shipbuilding, the Street Art Museum is the largest of its kind around the world. Not far from what museum curator Peter Ernst Cooler calls the “white cubes” (metaphor of those ivory-white-walled museums and galleries), it is an unusual place where all types of art are on display on the warehouse's various surfaces, from walls to structure poles. Moreover, the collection, which already counts more than 200 works from artists across the globe, spreads on the outside, in the streets and on the buildings of Amsterdam's Nieuw-West neighbourhood (within a 3-kilometer radius from the museum). Follow one of the urban guided tours along the city canals and listen to the stories of these incredible pieces, ranging from immigration issues to the environment. Among the possible tours, the Street Art Museum offers one with virtual reality helmets that unveils the work behind the frescoes, blending art and technology. Which should please kids and adults alike.

Street art museum
Immanuel Kanthof 1
1064 VR Amsterdam

+31 6 39482822

https://www.streetartmuseumamsterdam.com/

content.title: Wilde Zwijnen, local foodies' favourite

introduction.small: This is probably the most popular spot in Amsterdam among bistronomy lovers, yet it remains a secret for everyone else.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wilde Zwijnen, local foodies' favourite

paragraphs.text:
Try and live the life of a local Amsterdammer and pick one of their most popular addresses of the eastern part of town: Wilde Zwijnen. There, you will hear Dutch being spoken left and right, as the place is very much known and appreciated by locals, probably because it is not yet crowded with passing tourists. With its wooden tables, old chairs and clear-tone walls, the atmosphere switches from raw and countrylike to industrial and trendy.

Wilde Zwijnen means “wild boar“ in Dutch. You will therefore find many good meats on the menu, even though a few fish and vegetable options also make their way through. The three or four-course tasting menus change almost on a daily basis, highlighting seasonal and local products, like the lamb belly served with white asparagus and green peas, or the flank steak with salsa-verde-inspired sauce and pesto. The chef loves to cook delicate dishes, enhancing often-underestimated fruits and vegetables. Make way for beetroot al dente, Romanesco cabbage, green celery and bittersweet quinces. You will definitely need to make reservations.

Wilde Zwijnen
Javaplein 23
1095 CJ Amsterdam

+31 20 463 3043

http://wildezwijnen.nl/english.html

Menu: from 31.50 EUR

content.title: A day in Amsterdam – must-sees and quirky discoveries

introduction.small: Discover Amsterdam in a day – a lively and surprising, moving and secretive city… Wonderful memories are guaranteed.

paragraphs.text:
Gently riding and gliding along the canals

In the Netherlands, there are windmills, vast polders stretching to the horizon, tulip fields as far as the eye can see in spring… And then, there is Amsterdam, its vibrant, happening capital, where everyone seems to travel around by bike. So, hire one yourself – traditional or electric, tandem or individual – there are umpteen possibilities. You can even opt for a cool bike with a trailer to safely transport your kids. You have the right to cycle along streets in the opposite direction and ride through parks – you always have right of way. So, get on your bike and pedal along the 400 km of perfectly signposted cycle tracks. It is the perfect way to discover less touristy areas with a lot of charm as a result. You cross countless bridges on your way and cycle up and down lively streets lined with vintage, hip and interior-design boutiques and trendy restaurants. Eager to see Amsterdam in its entirety from a different, quirky angle, you give in to temptation and take a traditional cruise on the canals. You are not disappointed: your little boat trip rewards you with one-of-a-kind views of the city.

It is in one of these city-centre streets that you will find the Lion Noir restaurant where you decide to stop for lunch. If you need a bit of warmth, take a seat inside; the cosy atmosphere has eclectic, chic decor featuring bric-a-brac objects here and there. If you prefer to be in the open air, the terrace overflowing with hortensias is perfect for a meal or a cocktail in the evening. The menu boasts a cuisine that marries classic French dishes, spices from all four corners of the world and fresh, seasonal produce.

Before or after your gourmet break, travel back to Amsterdam's medieval past by exploring the Begijnhof founded in the 14th century. This large landscaped courtyard is lined by a row of houses forming a complex closed in on itself; in days gone by, it was home to lay religious women, or Beguines, who lived in the community isolated from the world. The only way into this hidden gem is through a door on Spui Square. As soon as you step over the threshold, you are struck by the tranquillity of the place; it is a real haven of peace and quiet. On your left, the Houten Huys is one of the two remaining wooden houses in the city. All around are red-brick facades and houses that are now owned by families whose children play happily in the grassy square. Do not forget to visit the clandestine church, hidden behind one of the dwellings. It symbolises the resistance of the Beguines who continued to practise Catholicism despite it being banned in the 17th and 18th centuries.

Lion Noir
Reguliersdwarsstraat 28
1017 BM Amsterdam
Netherlands
+31 (0)20 627 6603
../../common/travel-guide/lion-noir-the-gourmet-cabinet-of-curiosities-in-amsterdam.htm

Amsterdam Begijnhof
Begijnhof 30
Amsterdam
Netherlands

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

City grandeur in the Golden Age

Your city visit takes you to the house where Rembrandt lived from 1639 to 1656. You step inside into the everyday, private life of one of the greatest painters of the Dutch Golden Age. You can easily imagine the maestro at work on one of his masterpieces on the very spot where you are standing, as you soak up the special light of the place which made his paintings so magical. Today, in the studio, Rembrandt's prints rub shoulders with the canvases of contemporary artists. By discovering the treasures in this museum, you get that little bit closer to the creation of wonders of worldwide artistic heritage.

Without further ado, you continue your fabulous journey into the heart of Dutch painting by going to the Van Gogh Museum. Three centuries after Rembrandt, “the man with the severed ear” completely overturned the technique of painting. Amsterdam has dedicated an entire museum to him, displaying some of his greatest works, such as The Sower, The Potato Eaters and Almond Blossom. In all, there are some 200 paintings on show. As the collection is organised chronologically into five periods, you can follow the personal and artistic journey of Van Gogh step by step through 500 drawings and 700 handwritten letters, including his avid correspondence with his brother Theo. The museum also exhibits paintings by his contemporaries, artists who had an influence on the painter in one way or another. So, keep your eyes open and discover paintings by Gauguin, Monet, Signac, Toulouse-Lautrec, Kees van Dongen.... Just stunning! A word of advice: book your ticket in advance to avoid the queues.

Rembrandt House Museum
Jodenbreestraat 4
1011 NK Amsterdam
Netherlands
+31 (0)20 520 0400
https://www.rembrandthuis.nl/?lang=en

Van Gogh Museum
Museumplein 6
1071 DJ Amsterdam
Netherlands
+31 (0)20 570 5200
../../common/travel-guide/the-van-gogh-museum-get-to-know-vincent-better.htm

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

A moving experience at the Anne Frank House

The Netherlands paid a hefty price in the Second World War and the Jewish community in Amsterdam was not spared either. Bearing witness to this is the Anne Frank House located in the district of Jordaan, close to the Westerkerk church and at the side of the Prinsengracht canal. It was here that the young girl lived in hiding for two years with her family after the Germans invaded the Netherlands in 1940. It was also here that she wrote her famous diary until she was arrested and deported. The visit gives you an insight into her daily life as a child with its jumble of great fears and small joys. In every room you pass through, you are moved as you read extracts from her diary, reproduced on the walls. The emotion is palpable, and whether you are here with your children or not, you will be profoundly touched by the poignancy of the place. To make sure you get to visit the House, buy your ticket online a long time in advance.

For a cheerier kind of atmosphere, take the 30-minute walk to the Vondelpark. Named after the Dutch poet Joost van den Vondel, this park is a haven of nature laid out in the 19th century and loved by all Amsterdamers. You can walk along flower-lined pathways on the banks of small lakes, enjoy the shade at one of the romantic-looking bandstands, have a rest on the vast lawns or you might even be tempted to try a bit of rollerblading… A wonderful day in Amsterdam with plenty of things to do.

Anne Frank House
Westermarkt 20
1016 DK Amsterdam
Netherlands
+31 (0)20 556 7105
../../common/travel-guide/discover-the-anne-frank-house.htm

Discover other amazing and unusual places in our guide to Amsterdam.

content.title: Vermeer, pleasure to the senses

introduction.small: In the heart of Amsterdam, the Vermeer restaurant offers flavourful and colourful dishes cooked up by a Michelin-starred chef since 2005.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vermeer, pleasure to the senses

paragraphs.text:
Much as the layers of pigments and varnishes skilfully applied to the realistic masterpieces of painting that are The Milkmaid or Woman Reading a Letter, the Vermeer restaurant prepares generous dishes devised by British food genius Christopher Naylor, to the delight of all Amsterdam food lovers.

Rhubarb, mackerel, jumbo shrimp, hazelnut, asparagus, beetroot, lamb, passion fruit and ginger… All kinds of ingredients and fresh products supplied by local farms, in a promise of uncommon and tasty combinations. Located inside the Barbizon Palace, the kitchens of Vermeer have become Christopher Naylor and his crew's favourite playground, spreading a delightful scent over the streets of Amsterdam. Start out the evening with a fruity cocktail at the lounge bar, then choose a four, five or even six-course meal. At Vermeer's, the passion of great food talks…

Vermeer
Prins Hendrikkade 59-72
1021 AD Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 556 4885

www.restaurantvermeer.nl/en

Menu: 4-course for 70 EUR, 5-course for 85 EUR, 6-course for 100 EUR

content.title: Guts & Glory's logbook

introduction.small: Every three months, Guts & Glory opens a new culinary chapter, entirely dedicated to the gastronomy of a different country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Guts & Glory's logbook

paragraphs.text:
Nestled between a cosy hotel and a burger bar, only a few steps away from the very touristic Rembrandt Square, Guts & Glory is a particularly popular spot in Amsterdam. With its bright and design decor including canary-yellow bench seats, the restaurant pushes conceptual buttons. As if through a book, Guillaume de Beer and Freek Von Noortwisk tell their shared gastronomical story in sequences. First chapter: chicken. When the restaurant opened, the two chefs were studying one different animal every semester - hence the Bresse chicken, but also Wagyu beef or Iberian pork. They try all sorts of cooking variations and the simplest ways to sublimate the product, letting its fundamental flavours shine through. From then on, chapters have been dedicated to the national specialities of given countries that change every three months: Italy, the Netherlands, Thailand… "World cuisine" is never felt more apt!

Guts & Glory
Utrechtsestraat 6
1017 VN Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 362 0030

https://www.bredagroup-amsterdam.com/guts/?lang=en

Menu: from 49.50 EUR

content.title: QO Amsterdam, Europe's most sustainable hotel

introduction.small: An environmentally friendly culture prevails in this hotel, only two steps away from the banks of the Amstel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: QO Amsterdam, Europe's most sustainable hotel

paragraphs.text:
At QO Amsterdam, ecology is a way of life. With a self-sufficient greenhouse and an intelligent façade, the building is at the front line of sustainable development. You will be able to enjoy panoramic views and sip on a drink at the skybar located on the rooftop, where aquaponics has been set up (a natural ecosystem based on symbiosis between plants, fish and bacteria). The hotel farms vegetables, aromatic herbs as well as fish, all for its own restaurant serving typically Dutch food. The other products are all sourced from seasonal and local food networks, in accordance with life cycles.
Situated only five minutes away from the Spaklerweg and Somerlust park, QO Amsterdam aims to please its clientele with natural material and light-based decoration. Its modern architecture cleverly conceals an avant-garde energy-producing system: heat and cold are retained to supply heating and air conditioning. The attractive value for money of this innovative hotel definitely makes it an ideal spot to set up home while in Amsterdam.

QO Amsterdam
Amstelvlietstraat 4
1096 GG Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 220 5650

https://www.qo-amsterdam.com/

Rooms from 150 EUR

content.title: Yerba, plants in the spotlight

introduction.small: At the Yerba vegetarian restaurant, vegetables are the raw material.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yerba, plants in the spotlight

paragraphs.text:
With a carrot fest, a creamy tofu-based chocolate mousse, eggplant fritters with spices and wild mushrooms tartar, roasted eggplant, celery and onion mash, roasted Brussels sprouts served with a potato yogurt… You guessed it right: this trendy Amsterdam dining establishment gives vegetarian and vegan food pride of place. The menu changes seasonally, according to the whims of chef Walter Marskamp, and Yerba relies on local produce from responsible farmers.
In the semi-open kitchen, wasting is forbidden and sustainable development very much fostered. From roots to leaves, everything is usable, worked with and enriched to make up the best dishes and cocktails, served with or without alcohol. An omnivorous option is also available, offering locally sourced fish and meat on the gastronomical menu. Only open for dinner (exception being weekend brunch), the restaurant elegantly demonstrates that vegetables are way more than sides.

Yerba
Ruysdaelstraat 48
1071 XE Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 471 46 95

https://www.yerbabar.com

Menu: around 34 EUR

content.title: Mövenpick, a jewel between the city and the sea

introduction.small: In the Zeeburg district, the Mövenpick Hotel is a safe bet, only twenty minutes away from the airport.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mövenpick, a jewel between the city and the sea

paragraphs.text:
This four-star has everything to please you, starting with its location. Only five minutes away from the city centre, the hotel is a little off from all the city's restlessness, and allows you to enjoy access to the sea. Offering a view onto the mouth of the IJ river, the rooms all enjoy comfortable beds, a living room area and fully equipped charming bathrooms. Everything you might need is within your grasp, be it for professional or touristic stays.
The Silk Road restaurant prepares international, classic and quality food. As for cocktails, you can order them in the cosy setting of the Silk Bar. The hotel also counts very pleasant amenities and wellness installations, such as a Spa, a steam bath and a gym, which you can even use at night, after a long day of visits. For business requirements, note that you can arrange conferences and seminars. Our word of advice: the higher you get, the greater the view, so remember to book a room on a high floor!

Mövenpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre
Piet Heinkade 11
1019 BR Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 519 1200

https://www.movenpick.com/en/europe/netherlands/amsterdam/

Rooms: from 122 EUR

content.title: Spiritual stopover at Ons' Lieve Heer Op Solder

introduction.small: While Amsterdam's atmosphere moves more towards excitement than contemplation, visiting Ons' Lieve Heer Op Solder Museum, a national symbol of religious freedom, is a source of wonder.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spiritual stopover at Ons' Lieve Heer Op Solder

paragraphs.text:
The historic heart of Amsterdam offers a hidden treasure that has been religiously cared after since the Golden Age. In a magnificent manor house, built between 1661 and 1663 along a canal, is the Ons' Lieve Heer Op Solder Museum (in English, literally: "Our Lord in the Attic"). This mysterious name illustrates a fascinating story that you will discover by wandering through the three floors of the house.

It is on the top floor that its most precious relic is revealed. Instead of an old and dusty attic, you will find an exquisite clandestine church. This secret place of prayer was commissioned by its former owner, a rich Catholic merchant, at the time when Holland was still governed by the Protestant Reformation. The pious shopkeeper thus invited God and his flock to his home to pray for their salvation in the utmost secrecy. A magnificent spiritual place to be amazed and gather your thoughts.

Ons' Lieve Heer Op Solder
Oudezijds Voorburgwal 38
1012 GD Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 624 6604

https://www.opsolder.nl

content.title: The Hoxton, bohemian chic refuge

introduction.small: While there is a plethora of accommodation possibilities in the Dutch capital, The Hoxton is one of its most beautiful jewels… and the top address for discerning travellers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hoxton, bohemian chic refuge

paragraphs.text:
Between the Singel and Herengracht canals, this is the first hotel of British brand Hoxton in Amsterdam. While the four-star establishment immediately impresses with the red-brick facades of a former bank and five buildings from the 17th century coming together, its interiors exude conviviality. Mustard yellow and orange velvet unfold on soft armchairs, while camel leather shines on Chesterfield sofas decorated with mismatched cushions. From the library to the winter garden, trendy clientele treads upon the solid wood flooring and colourful kilim rugs. The "shoebox", "cosy", "roomy" and "concept" establishment's 111 rooms combine vintage furniture with contemporary design pieces, offering a bohemian and trendy refuge to delighted guests.

Before leaving the hotel, stop by the photo booth in the spacious lobby in order to take away a nice souvenir from your stay in this temple of style.

The Hoxton
Herengracht 255
1016 BJ Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 888 5555

https://thehoxton.com/holland/amsterdam/hotels

Rooms: from 199 EUR

content.title: Het Grachtenhuis Museum, Amsterdam's fluvial history

introduction.small: Discover the history of Amsterdam's canals at Het Grachtenhuis Museum, an essential visit to understand the city's unique relationship with the meanders it is comprised of.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Het Grachtenhuis Museum, Amsterdam's fluvial history

paragraphs.text:
One of the charms of the Dutch capital is undoubtedly its iconic maze of canals that has irrigated the city since 1600. They have been listed as UNESCO World Heritage since 2010.

Het Grachtenhuis Museum, sheltered in a charming red brick house which is listed as a national monument, contains archives dating back to the genesis of this monumental project, defying all the laws of physics and tracing its evolution across the ages.

Upon entry, you will be assigned to a small group to discover the history of the canal belt and the expansion of the city since the 17th century, along a captivating interactive journey... On top of the incredible architecture, you will also learn about daily life along the canals for merchants, visitors and inhabitants alike. Models, holograms, videos and cartoons allow you to relive 400 years of Amsterdam's history in a fun and educational way, over just 40 minutes...

Het Grachtenhuis Museum
Herengracht 386
1016 CJ Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 421 1656

www.hetgrachtenhuis.nl/en/

content.title: Return to the Golden Age at Van Loon Museum

introduction.small: In Amsterdam's historic district, a splendid family home also serves as a museum, six days a week, taking visitors on an extraordinary journey back in time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Return to the Golden Age at Van Loon Museum

paragraphs.text:
In a charming noble residence along a canal stands a splendid museum that will take you back for a visit to the Dutch Golden Age... Built in 1672, then home to Ferdinand Bol, a renowned portrait painter and pupil of Rembrandt, the building was purchased in 1884 by the Van Loon family, co-founder of the famous East India Company.
Although the property remains private and partially inhabited to this day, it has been open to the public since 1973. Take a walk in the beautiful French-style gardens and wander through the four floors of the residence to discover an extraordinary collection of paintings, furniture, porcelain pieces and silverware from the 18th century... From the entrance hall to the bedrooms and the kitchen, the decor has not lost any of its former splendour, immersing you in the rich past of the Dutch aristocracy,

Van Loon Museum
Keizersgracht 672
1017 ET Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 624 5255

https://www.museumvanloon.nl

Admission: 9 EUR

content.title: The way by Stork

introduction.small: An early morning stroll in Amsterdam's cobbled alleys will certainly awaken your appetite. You are invited to discover Stork's unique atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The way by Stork

paragraphs.text:
In the De Overkant industrial park, aromas from Stork's kitchen will tickle your senses, while you remain fascinated by the surrounding decor. The silent water of the IJ Lake hits the sides of a vast terrace for short moments as ships pass by. Once inside, the majestic setting will leave you speechless: under breathtaking high ceilings, circular tables and redesigned crates mingle around a well-stocked bar.
Militant about respectful fishing, Stork fills plates and hearts with shellfish and crustaceans. On the menu, seafood in all forms: whole crab or just claws and legs, halibut, mackerel, salmon, clams, vongole, oysters and prawns dance in dishes generously prepared by the chef. Add a sip of dry white wine, which should marry well with the maritime flavours of your dish. Enjoy the lakefront by finishing with a peaceful ride on one of the city's free barges.

Café-restaurant Stork
Gedempt Hamerkanaal 201
1021 KP Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 634 4000

https://restaurantstork.nl/en/

Menu: from 30 EUR

content.title: A country visit at the Keukenhof

introduction.small: Just an hour from Amsterdam, visit one of the most beautiful floral parks in the world!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A country visit at the Keukenhof

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the Bollenstreek region and its vast flower fields, lie the famous enchanted gardens of Keukenhof. Visitors flock to the breathtaking spectacle in the first days of spring: more than seven million daffodils, roses, orchids and hyacinths burst into a symphony of colours on the estate's 30 hectares.

Of all the flowers here, the undisputed star is the tulip, which you will admire in no fewer than 800 varieties. This bright and graceful flower was introduced to Holland at the end of the 16th century, and its popularity was such that the Dutch made it their emblem.

Sumptuous floral exhibitions are held at the Keukenhof in the springtime, from late March to mid-May. Be sure to visit the park's three pavilions, including the Beatrix Greenhouse, home to the largest collection of orchids in the world. What a nice place to stroll and daydream!

Keukenhof Park
Stationsweg 166A
2161 AM Lisse

+31 (0)25 246 5555

www.keukenhof.nl/en/

Entry: 17 EUR

content.title: Stylish uniqueness at the Hotel V Fizeaustraat

introduction.small: "From Amsterdam with love" is the slogan of this sumptuous hotel a few minutes from Amstel. Plan for a lovely night in the Venice of the North.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stylish uniqueness at the Hotel V Fizeaustraat

paragraphs.text:
Designed by architect Piet Zanstra, the building is surrounded with greenery. The cosy reception hall with exposed foundations, illuminated by delicate candles and eccentric chandeliers, is an invitation to travel where "all is order and beauty, luxury, peace and pleasure" as Baudelaire wrote.

Once you open the door to your room, you enter a vast space of unusual charm. Around a generous-sized bed where four velvety pillows await you, discover an industrial space punctuated with exotic touches: woven fabrics on the walls, bamboo chairs and Scandinavian sofas are all elements that make for the attraction of the hotel. Finally, in a 1970s atmosphere, the Lobby Fizeaustraat declares an avowed love to gastronomy. The promise of an elegant day, Amsterdam style.

Hotel V Fizeaustraat
Fizeaustraat 2
1097 SC Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 662 3233

https://hotelvfizeaustraat.nl/en

Rooms: from 84 EUR

content.title: The Sir Adam Hotel, the most beautiful view of Amsterdam

introduction.small: This hotel, perched on the right bank of the city, combines luxury, modernity and design - as much in its exterior architecture as in its interior decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Sir Adam Hotel, the most beautiful view of Amsterdam

paragraphs.text:
In Amsterdam's Noord district, this charming hotel is a big hit. All day long, ferries shuttle between the city centre and the hotel to allow you to enjoy a wonderful stay, a little outside of the hustle and bustle of the city. The rooms have a breathtaking view over the IJ River with Amsterdam lit up at night in the background. The rooms are perfectly equipped and offer irreproachable comfort and, above all, are very nicely decorated with vintage objects (books, trinkets and photos) that make the room feel cosy and welcoming. The hotel has more to offer than just beds, there are lounges to relax in after a day on your feet, an observatory perched at the top of the hotel to admire the panorama, and The Butcher Social Club- a superb bar for good meat and a party. A hotel to discover as soon as you can!

Sir Adam Hotel
Overhoeksplein 7
1031 KS Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 215 9500

https://www.sirhotels.com/en/adam

Rooms: from 129 EUR

content.title: Gourmet getaway among the stands of the Foodhallen

introduction.small: The Foodhallen is located in a large Amsterdam warehouse where tramway cars were once parked. Discover a trendy concept.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gourmet getaway among the stands of the Foodhallen

paragraphs.text:
The teal blue doors of the Foodhallen open onto a grandiose urban loft-like space. The sun's rays penetrate through the roof to light the tables and wooden benches, make the glasses shimmer on the long counters and bathe more than 20 restaurateurs in light. From a Michelin-starred chef to international culinary stands, the building draws its inspiration from the indoor markets of Copenhagen and Madrid, revealing a cosmopolitan air suffused with finesse.

Masterfully designed by Dutch architect André van Stigt, this huge gourmet hall brings together international fare with alternative cuisines, most prepared as you wait. Share some bitterballen (Dutch meatballs) with truffles or perhaps bouillabaisse style, or mouth-watering pieces of shredded pork in barbecue sauce, fried vegetables, falafels and hummus or seafood buns. Escape to Spain for a plate of tapas or dive into the heart of Hong Kong for a few dim sum. Eat in or take away?

 

Foodhallen
Bellamyplein 51
1053 AT Amsterdam

+31 (0)62 926 5037

https://fhttps://foodhallen.nl

Menu: prices vary depending on the food stands

content.title: Lion Noir, the gourmet cabinet of curiosities

introduction.small: In the heart of Amsterdam, this French restaurant sets itself apart by its imposing and original decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lion Noir, the gourmet cabinet of curiosities

paragraphs.text:
The kitchens of the Lion Noir send fragrant scents into the streets of Amsterdam. The walls of an intense olive green are covered with paintings from yesteryear, portraits, and an oddity or two (birdcages and model airplanes hang from the ceiling), giving the restaurant an unusual charm. Couples toast their evenings in the warm light, a group of friends has an intense discussion at the bar between sips of their drinks. There is a New York speakeasy feeling in the air.

If you visit the Lion Noir for lunch, you might be tempted by the braised pork bruschetta and pickled vegetables, unless you prefer a truffle risotto with green asparagus, parmesan and a poached egg. In the evening, enjoy some sautéed scallops and grilled squid in creamy salsa, then continue with a fillet of lamb with preserved lemon. Finally, the nut-flavoured crème brûlée with figs and caramel ice cream delicately closes this feast. Feel free to take a walk in the garden, considered one of the best spots in the city.

Lion Noir
Reguliersdwarsstraat 28
1017 BM Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 627 6603

https://lionnoir.nl

Menu: from 30 EUR

content.title: The Pantry, honouring Dutch culinary traditions

introduction.small: Let yourself be tempted by the atmosphere and generous cooking at The Pantry, nestled on a lively little street in the Leidseplein.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pantry, honouring Dutch culinary traditions

paragraphs.text:
The first word that comes to mind to describe this traditional Dutch restaurant is "nice". Nice for its homey atmosphere and meals prepared entirely in their kitchens. The cuisine of this neighbourhood establishment does not seek to be refined, just traditional and good. The Dutch dishes are typical, with mashed potatoes, sausages, sauerkraut and meatballs. Enjoy a beef stew served with red cabbage and mash potatoes, or marinated pork ribs with delicious homemade French fries.

Inside, the small dining room is decorated with museum-worthy paintings and a collection of vintage plates. Harking back to the Golden Age, the décor undeniably contributes to the unique atmosphere. The owner manages her restaurant with an overflowing vitality and generosity. The Pantry is quite popular among travellers, as it strives to maintain an intimate atmosphere and excellent value with a high-quality level.

The Pantry
Leidsekruisstraat 21
1017 RE Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 620 0922

https://www.thepantry.nl/en/

Menu: around 21.50 EUR

content.title: The Rue des Consuls: the shopping street

introduction.small: At the heart of the medina, this charming market alley has a name that sounds like the title of a novel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Rue des Consuls: the shopping street

paragraphs.text:
The ‘Rue des Consuls' owes its name to the ambassadors and consuls who have long lived on this street in the middle of the medina. Do you know why they set up here? When Rabat was a city of pirates, a treaty signed with the sultan allowed them to redeem Christian captives, the sale of which took place two steps away, on the Place des Oudayas.

Since then, the street has become an uninterrupted row of stalls. Unlike other souks, vendors are not insistent in Rabat. The atmosphere is friendly. Though the DVD traders are unavoidable, all that is sold here is manufactured in the workshops of the medina, including the carpets, because Rabat is the capital of the carpet. Dyed red for the most part, they are hand made, lock stitched by the Rabatians. Or let yourself be tempted by metal jewellery or a goat-leather wallet—or order a nice pair of sandals in raffia tailored especially for you.

content.title: The Student Hotel Amsterdam City, a hybrid hotel

introduction.small: This designer address has the singular charm of a hostel and the full comfort of a hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Student Hotel Amsterdam City, a hybrid hotel

paragraphs.text:
Overnight or for six months, it's entirely up to you. This innovative hotel concept is at the crossroads of accommodation genres and dreams to pursue in cosy and stylish rooms. Aparthotel 2.0. for students, it also welcomes globetrotters, young start-up entrepreneurs, and their families. The rooms are comfortable and smartly designed. The common spaces invite exchange while protecting privacy. Besides the kitchenettes in some rooms, a common kitchen allows you to cook a meal while chatting with travellers and students from around the world. Unless, of course, you prefer the restaurant.

Also available are workrooms and a gym, laundry facilities, Wi-Fi, and bikes to rent. The Student Hotel Amsterdam City is the newest address of the Student Hotel group and the second in Amsterdam. Launched in 2012 in Rotterdam by Charlie MacGregor, the idea has spread from the Netherlands to Spain and France.

The Student Hotel Amsterdam City
Wibautstraat 129
1091 GL Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 214 9999

https://www.thestudenthotel.com/amsterdam-city

Rooms: from 72 EUR

content.title: Happyhappyjoyjoy is wonderfulwonderful

introduction.small: Asian street food in a setting of supercharged colours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Happyhappyjoyjoy is wonderfulwonderful

paragraphs.text:
The name says it all. You will find here a little of the lively street-food atmosphere that gives Asian markets their unique charm. Designed by Concrete Design, the decor is gloriously pop, with red umbrellas hanging from the ceiling, kitschy colourful posters on the walls, and dinner plates glued to the walls like Smarties. The imagery recalls the film In the Mood for Love, Wong Kar-wai's famous film. The semi-open kitchen looks like a ship container and the food is a mix of Thai, Malaysian, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Chinese, and Korean. The menu highlights are the phở bò soup, Pad Thai noodles, tofu, and Tom Yum shrimp with chillies. Unless you would rather have some dim sum (duck, chicken, shrimp, pork, vegetables… they are all here). The restaurant also offers vegetarian options. Spicy and delicious, as it should be.

Happyhappyjoyjoy
Bilderdijkstraat 158HS
1053 LC Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 344 6433

https://happyhappyjoyjoy.asia/en

Menu: around 22 EUR

content.title: Choose from 1 to 5 stars at The Exchange

introduction.small: Choose the size and the comfort of your room and pay accordingly.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Choose from 1 to 5 stars at The Exchange

paragraphs.text:
Near Dam Square is a hotel created by graduates of the Amsterdam Fashion Institute, which is to say young people at the cutting edge of new fashion and consumer spending trends.

Its concept is original: the rooms are categorized by star rating so that every budget finds a place. According to the chosen category, the room's size, view, furnishings, and even toiletries are different, ranging from the very modest to top of the line. Naturally every room has an individual décor, where the sometimes-violent colour palette comes first. The young, trendy clientele appreciate the contemporary design shop, where you can find objects available nowhere else.

Finally, the hotel's Stock café offers sandwiches, homemade cakes,  and fresh smoothies in a relaxed environment for conversations with  other guests.

The Exchange
Damrak 50
1012 LL Amsterdam

+31 20 523 0080

www.hoteltheexchange.com

Rooms: from 88 EUR

content.title: Wander in Vondelpark

introduction.small: A relaxing break in the shade: tourists and locals alike enjoy Vondelpark.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wander in Vondelpark

paragraphs.text:
At the end of the 1960s, hippies made this one of their favourite locations. Today, everyone likes to walk in this park, one of the city's biggest, because of its calm. You can stop here after visiting the Van Gogh Museum or the nearby Rijksmuseum.

This green enclave, 47 hectares in size, is frequented by locals in all seasons. Here, joggers work their way through winding paths, while, elsewhere, cyclists finish their morning ride and rollerbladers perform daring tricks. The gardens are perfectly manicured. If you have time, stretch out on the grass and consider the museums you've just seen, or maybe have a picnic as a family or with your lover.

In the summertime the open-air theatre offers concerts. Nearby you can see the Hollandsche Manege, a horse-riding school. The Vondelpark is easily accessible by tramway.

content.title: The Begijnhof: an oasis of calm

introduction.small: Looking for tranquillity? Take a few moments' rest while discovering the Begijnhof.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Begijnhof: an oasis of calm

paragraphs.text:
The Begijnhof was originally a convent for pious, charitable single women called Begijnen. Today this historic site, with its gorgeous gabled houses and gardens, has been restored to such perfection that it almost resembles a movie set. With its hundred-year-old trees and charming little gardens, it is an enclave of greenery that provides a welcome contrast to the noise of the city. Most of the houses were built in the 17th and 18th centuries; the oldest, of wood, goes all the way back to the end of the 15th century. You can see it at #34, at the end of the courtyard. Originally a convent for Beguine nuns, devout single women open to charity (the last died in 1971), it now houses women, generally students, who still live here today. Appreciate the contemplative atmosphere of the Catholic chapel at #29. Enter the Begijnhof through a little door near the bustling Spui crossroads; pedestrians are welcome.

Begijnhof
Begijnhof 30
Amsterdam

https://begijnhofkapelamsterdam.nl/english-information/

content.title: Travel by bike

introduction.small: For the Dutch, the bicycle is the ideal mode of transport. Do as they do: discover the city on two wheels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Travel by bike

paragraphs.text:
Cars are not recommended for visiting Amsterdam, and the price of parking is very high. In all seasons, the bike is queen here everyone, whether a child or a retiree, owns one.

For a visitor, bicycles are easily rented, providing the perfect means for discovering the different neighbourhoods of the city, alone or as a family. You will ride along canals and cross flower-covered bridges, and you will discover parks in which to rest after pedalling. In order to safely enjoy your wanderings, it is recommended that you strictly respect traffic regulations: drive on the right side of the road, obey all signs, and, in particular, be alert at tramway crossings because they can be dangerous. Also, be sure to securely lock your bike whenever you stop, even if just to take a photo, or it may quickly disappear.

content.title: The beautiful, newly restored Rijksmuseum

introduction.small: It holds a gigantic collection of masterpieces from the Dutch Golden Age.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The beautiful, newly restored Rijksmuseum

paragraphs.text:
Vermeer's The Milkmaid or Woman in Blue Reading a Letter, Rembrandt's The Night Watch (1642) or The Jewish Bride (1667): the invention of "chiaroscuro" made these four works universally celebrated. All are presented here. However, many other treasures may also be found in this immense museum, built in 1885, yet comfortably modern: 30,000 art objects, 17,000 historical documents, 5,000 paintings, including those by Jan Steen and Frans Hals. Sculpture and decorative arts through the centuries are also given pride of place so enthusiasts, take note.

In fact, here you are invited to take a voyage through art history from the Middle Ages until the 20th century. Even if you are not a student of art history, you will be amazed by this collection presented over four floors in this neo-Gothic building. Set aside ample time for a visit: you will not be disappointed.

Rijksmuseum
Museumstraat 1
1071 XX Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 674 7000

https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en

content.title: The Royal Palace: a must-see

introduction.small: Formerly the mayor's office, the Royal Palace is now only used for official receptions. It still holds treasures from the Golden Age.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Royal Palace: a must-see

paragraphs.text:
Built in the 17th century by architect Jacob van Campen, this classically austere construction was intended to be Amsterdam's city hall.

On the roof, a statue representing Peace holds an olive branch, accompanied by Prudence and Justice. A symbol of the city's prosperity, this imposing building became a royal palace when Napoleon put his brother Louis on the throne.

Louis changed the layout and had a balcony installed on the facade. The interior, which is easy to get lost in, is absolutely splendid: decorated rooms, sculptures, paintings, and statues…

Don't miss the small courtroom in which the death penalty used to be handed down, the community hall built into the foundation, the justice chambers, or the city council room. The style and architecture represent the Dutch Golden Age very well.

Royal Palace
Dam Square
1012 NP Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 522 6161

https://www.paleisamsterdam.nl/en

content.title: The Van Gogh Museum, to better understand Vincent

introduction.small: See the world's biggest collection of Vincent Van Gogh's paintings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Van Gogh Museum, to better understand Vincent

paragraphs.text:
This museum is dedicated to Vincent Van Gogh but also presents the work of some of his contemporaries.

It possesses the richest collection of his work: hundreds of drawings, sketches, studies, and more than 200 paintings. They are presented according to five chronological periods corresponding to major periods in the life of the painter: in the Netherlands, Paris, Arles, Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, and finally Auvers-sur-Oise, in the Paris region, where he committed suicide in July 1890.

This last period of his life was especially fertile, as the portraits of Dr. Gachet and his daughter and his country landscapes attest. Works that inspired Van Gogh, such as Japanese prints, are also presented.

The building was constructed at the beginning of the 1970s and an additional wing was added in 1999. Arm yourself with patience before you go: due to its success, lines can be long. Save some time and visit the museum as it opens in the morning!

Van Gogh Museum
Museumplein 6
1071 DJ Amsterdam

+31 20 570 5200

https://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/en

content.title: Take a look at the Moooi Gallery

introduction.small: The talent of Dutch designer Marcel Wanders is found here. It's a gallery that is worth a look.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take a look at the Moooi Gallery

paragraphs.text:
Fans of this star of Dutch design will enjoy seeing this gallery, which opened in 2008 and expanded in 2011. Its name is derived from the word mooi which means “beautiful” in Dutch. Tucked away in Jordaan, a fashionable neighbourhood, it brings Wanders' entire universe to life. He's the creator of the very sophisticated decor of the Andaz Hotel in Amsterdam.

In 1996, Wanders created the Knotted Chair, which became a coveted collector's item. Recently, the Stedelijk Museum highlighted the 20-year anniversary of the artist, who said, ‘A well-thought out design celebrates the quality of the relationship between itself and its audience.' Wanders has inspired other iconoclastic designers.

Don't be surprised if some furniture or objects seem strange: here, you are at the extreme avant-garde of contemporary design.

Moooi Gallery
Westerstraat 187
1015 MA Amsterdam

+31 20 528 7760

https://www.moooi.com

content.title: The Flower Market, symbol of Amsterdam

introduction.small: You may just be looking, but buying flowers of every colour imaginable has never been easier.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Flower Market, symbol of Amsterdam

paragraphs.text:
It is well known that the Netherlands is a country not only of diamonds and cheese, but also of flowers. The tulip, which first became popular here in 1594 after being imported from the Ottoman Empire, has become a national symbol.

Bulbs can be bought in many places but especially at this floating flower market, the only one of its kind in the world, as it takes place on riverboats docked along the Singel canal between Koningsplein and Muntplein. The market dates to the end of the 19th century. You will have rarely seen such colour, which changes according to the seasons. Thousands of fresh flowers are available for purchase at the stands, as are bulbs that you can plant at home in flowerboxes, balconies, or gardens.

The best moment to plant is between September and the beginning of December. Your flowers will bud in the spring.

Flower Market
Singel Canal
1071 Amsterdam

www.amsterdamsights.com/shopping/bloemensingel.html

content.title: The Lloyd Hotel & Cultural Embassy: rooms and events

introduction.small: Enjoy this hotel, which combines comfortable rooms with cultural events.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Lloyd Hotel & Cultural Embassy: rooms and events

paragraphs.text:
s was the first hotel in the world to offer unique rooms ranging from one to five stars. The Dutch do know how to surprise… Its building is listed as Historical Heritage in the Netherlands. First conceived as an inn for immigrant workers in the 1920, then a borstal, it had further down the line been used by art studios until its renovation was completed in 2004. More than 50 designers and artists participated in the hotel's decoration. Their nearly limitless imagination is displayed throughout the 117 charming rooms. There is something for everyone, from globetrotters looking a cheap stay to businessmen who favour their comfort.

You will also be able to enjoy the cultural embassy, which offers guests thorough cultural information and offers an endless supply of shows.

The Lloyd Hotel & Cultural Embassy
Oostelijke Handelskade 34
1019 BN Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 561 3636

https://lloyd.nl

Rooms: from 50 EUR

content.title: The NEMO: because science is a game

introduction.small: A ship run aground? No, it's the surprising NEMO science centre, which pleases both adults and kids.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The NEMO: because science is a game

paragraphs.text:
Open to the public in 2000, the NEMO is Amsterdam's science museum.

Designed by Italian architect Renzo Piano, it recalls a green-coloured ship emerging from the water. Its avant-garde architecture is just as impressive as the exhibits presented there, which are popular with the young and old alike. These exhibits are regularly renewed in order to keep up with the latest technological developments. Here, you can learn, as well as have fun.

In this deliberately hands-on museum, prepare to be more of a participant than a spectator. In a futuristic atmosphere, you can play with interactive installations to develop your knowledge of chemistry, biology, and computer science. The rooftop terrace offers a terrific view of Amsterdam and, in the summer, there is a café-restaurant.

Because the museum is quite crowded, especially during school vacations, try to begin your visit with the top floor, opposite to the approach of most visitors.

NEMO
Oosterdok 2
1011 VX Amsterdam

+31 20 531 3233

https://www.nemosciencemuseum.nl/en/

content.title: A walk in Haarlem

introduction.small: Haarlem is only 20 minutes by train: tulips, pedestrian areas, and museums…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A walk in Haarlem

paragraphs.text:
As soon as you arrive at the station in Haarlem, you find that you are in a haven of peace, though only 20 kilometres away. If you have planned to stay for several days in the Netherlands, a visit to Haarlem is worth the break from Amsterdam's frenzy.

The city also offers many historical sites of major interest. Wander in the cobblestoned streets, admire the Renaissance facade of City Hall, and get lost in the Grote Markt, a market that is hundreds of years old… You can admire the gigantic stained-glass windows of the Romano-Byzantine-inspired, neo-Gothic Cathedral of Saint Bavo.

As for the Frans Hals Museum, it holds striking works, including the painter's Banquet of the Officers of the Saint Adrien Militia Company (1627). Finally, the Teylers Museum, the Netherlands' oldest, founded by a wealthy merchant at the end of the 18th century, presents a unique collection touching on sciences and the arts.

Haarlem Tourism Office
Grote Markt 2
2011 RD Haarlem

+31 23 531 7325

https://www.visithaarlem.com/en

content.title: By train to The Hague

introduction.small: Political capital of the Netherlands, The Hague holds many historical and cultural treasures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: By train to The Hague

paragraphs.text:
The Hague is where the government and the Dutch sovereigns reside. Regarded as the country's political capital, this city, only 35 minutes by train from Amsterdam, is worth the visit. There is a charming historical neighbourhood and several monuments such as the Parliament and the Binnenhof, a Gothic brick palace that houses the core of the Dutch Government.

Inside the Binnenhof, visit the Ridderzall, the knights' hall where the king gives her opening speech to the General Assembly every year. Also be sure to visit the Mauritshuis, the museum which houses the impressive royal art collection, which includes works by Rembrandt and Vermeer, notably his Girl with a Pearl Earring.

The Hague is also home to the Peace Palace, financed by American philanthropist Andrew Carnegie, where the International Court of Justice was created in 1946.

The Hague Tourism Office
Spui 68
2511 BT Den Haag

+31 70 361 8860

https://denhaag.com/en

content.title: Have a beer at the Heineken brewery

introduction.small: The most famous of local brews, Heineken was born in Amsterdam. Visit the old factory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Have a beer at the Heineken brewery

paragraphs.text:
The former brewery, built of red brick and located a few streets away from the Rijksmuseum in the Pijp neighbourhood, was closed in 1988. It's not really missed by its neighbours, who were often disturbed by its odours. It was turned into a museum and then renovated in 2008 for the pleasure of beer lovers from all over the world.

The recipe for Heineken beer has been jealously guarded since Gerard Adriaan Heineken acquired the factory in 1864 and made a fortune for his family. However, the interactive visit still explains the process by which this national drink, consumed in the millions of litres in the country and all over the world, is made.

Thanks to sophisticated multimedia tools, you will learn about all aspects of the brand. Naturally, the visit of about an hour and a half is capped off with an enjoyable tasting, in moderation.

Heineken Brewery
Stadhouderskade 78
1072 AE Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 523 9435

https://www.amsterdam.info/heineken-experience/

content.title: Bargain hunting at Waterlooplein

introduction.small: Everything can be found at the flea market: clothing, objects, books.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bargain hunting at Waterlooplein

paragraphs.text:
Hunt for treasures at Waterloopein near the Stadhuis-Muziektheater complex and Rembrandt's house. Open six days a week (closed Sundays), nearly everything can be found in this outdoor market: new or old trinkets and clothes, tools and furniture, and numerous curiosities. Even if you're not looking to buy, don't hesitate to stroll around between tables and under shelves.

You may still have a chance of finding a vintage treasure, restored or in its original condition. Curious tourists, penniless students, and people from all walks of life can be found here. Everyone uses their best bargaining skills to get the best price. Will you be able to buy at your asking price? Keep a watchful eye out for pickpockets, who often make the best deals of all…

Waterlooplein Flea Market
Waterlooplein
1011 Amsterdam
https://waterlooplein.amsterdam/en/

content.title: Dam Square

introduction.small: Stroll and admire the facade of the Royal Palace… Dam Square is the very heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dam Square

paragraphs.text:
This square's name refers to the dam built on the Amstel River in the 13th century, which united two settlements and created the city. The dam has long symbolised the city's power. Amsterdam's central square, it remains, as in the past, a place of permanent agitation, always very animated. It's a popular meeting place as well as a historical area and an important commercial zone. Meet friends, wander, and admire the beautiful Royal Palace with its sculpted pediments overlooking the square. Don't miss the Nieuwe Kerk “New Church” nearby, which was built in the 15th century. Gothic in style, the church has been modified many times over the years. It is where the country's sovereigns have always been crowned. Of particular interest, in a relatively austere interior, are the pipe organs and the Baroque-style pulpit from 1648. In summer, Dam Square is invaded by families with prams, musicians, street vendors, and, inevitably, pickpockets, so be sure to keep an eye on your belongings as you stroll the area.

Dam Square
Dam 2
1012 NP Amsterdam

content.title: An unforgettable cruise on the canals

introduction.small: A good way to discover the magnificent waterfronts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An unforgettable cruise on the canals

paragraphs.text:
Amsterdam is characterised by its canals to the point that it is sometimes considered the 'Venice of the North.' The canals stretch for kilometres. Stroll along the must-see Singel, Herengracht, Keizersgracht, or Prinsensgracht canals, which have been at the city's centre since the 17th century. They were listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2010.

Crossed by little bridges, bordered by traditional homes, they have an enchanting charm. You can spend hours taking in the atmosphere and strolling along the canal banks. The most pleasant is without a doubt the Prinsengracht, near Anne Frank's house, which is bordered by numerous cafés.

Several boat companies offer guided visits, which are even more magical at sunset, when the light becomes soft and the beautiful homes begin to light up. Candlelight cruises are also organised on weekends.

content.title: Get lost in the De Pijp neighbourhood

introduction.small: It has always welcomed newcomers: yesterday it was immigrants, now it is artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Get lost in the De Pijp neighbourhood

paragraphs.text:
The name comes from the long and narrow streets, which are shaped like pipes and their joints. Take a walk south of the canals, as this area, off the beaten path of classic tours, is worth getting to know.

Parts of the area represent an exemplary sense of urban planning, thanks to urban architect Hendrik Petrus Berlage whose statue, armed with pencil and compass, can be found on Victorieplein square. Alongside is a 12-storey skyscraper, rare in Amsterdam, designed by Arthur Staal.

Long inhabited by foreigners, particularly immigrants, the sector is becoming gentrified. Artists, students, intellectuals, and gay citizens have made it a favourite haunt for its bohemian, poetic, and particularly free-spirited atmosphere.

In spite of the creeping gentrification, a crowd of great cafés and restaurants can be found here that are often moderately priced. Enjoy!

content.title: Catch a flick at the Tuschinski Theatre

introduction.small: Soon to be a hundred years old, this cinema barely survived the Second World War but its Art Deco styling is still just as beautiful as when it was built.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Catch a flick at the Tuschinski Theatre

paragraphs.text:
This 'picture palace' was founded in 1921 by Abraham Tuschinski, a Polish Jewish immigrant deported from the Netherlands to Auschwitz and murdered during the Second World War. Now a cinema complex with several screens, its Art Deco finishings have been preserved in spite of the years.

They're remarkable: a profusion of lights, stained glass, murals, carpets… Everything is so extraordinarily luxurious, for a moment you might think you're in a Hollywood film. The Dutch don't hesitate to call it the most beautiful cinema in the world, and they may be right. The site has been in continuous use for decades.

However, it was nearly destroyed during the German occupation when a group of Nazis set it on fire. Ask politely to visit the large theatre between two screenings; the personnel will be glad to oblige. The theatre is easy to find in the southern canal zone.

Pathé Tuschinski Theatre
Reguliersbreestraat 26-34
1017 CN Amsterdam

+31 20 900 1458

https://en.pathe.nl/

content.title: Modern art at the Stedelijk Museum

introduction.small: Kasimir Malevich, Piet Mondrian, Henri Matisse… they are all exhibited here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Modern art at the Stedelijk Museum

paragraphs.text:
This museum brings together one of the Netherlands' best collections of modern and contemporary art. The neo-Renaissance building, built in 1895, was renovated and enlarged in 2012. Drawing on its remarkable store of paintings, sculptures, drawings, engravings, and photographs, the museum principally highlights artistic movements of the latter half of the 20th century, such as the CoBrA movement (group of artists created in 1948), New Realism, and Pop Art.

Don't miss works by Karel Appel, Jean Dubuffet, and Wassily Kandinsky. A large section is devoted to the paintings of Russian painter Kasimir Malevich. Pushing abstraction to its furthest extreme, he painted the untitled white square on a white background in 1915.

You will also find works by post-war American artists such as Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, and Roy Lichtenstein. Contemporary exhibits dedicated to young artists of the Dutch artistic scene complete the ensemble.

Museumplein 10
1071 DJ Amsterdam

+31 20 573 2911

https://www.stedelijk.nl

content.title: De Kas: an ecologically minded restaurant with its own produce

introduction.small: Here, everything is fresh. Vegetables come from the garden, which can be visited before dining.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: De Kas: an ecologically minded restaurant with its own produce

paragraphs.text:
This large greenhouse, dating from 1926 in the centre of Frankendael park, was about to be demolished in 2001, when starred chef, Gert Jan Hageman, decided to turn it into an original restaurant with its own garden.

As such, all vegetables, herbs, and edible flowers are cultivated here, in this same garden, from May to October, and guests are even invited to visit it. Otherwise, produce is sourced from another neighbouring garden, less than 10 kilometres away. Meats and fish are sourced exclusively from local providers. Lunch or dine at large wooden tables underneath the superb, eight-metre-high glass roof.

Each day's menu is created according to the day's harvest. Be sure to reserve your table, and don't miss one of the house specialties: a Champagne cocktail infused with basil and lemon. The wine selection is reasonably priced and obviously better enjoyed in moderation.

 

De Kas
Kamerlingh Onneslaan 3
1097 DE Amsterdam

+31 20 462 4562

https://restaurantdekas.com/eng/about-de-kas

Menu: from 35.50 EUR

content.title: La Oliva, Spanish dishes for everybody to enjoy

introduction.small: Taste the best products the Iberian Peninsula has to offer, from cheeses to pata negra hams.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Oliva, Spanish dishes for everybody to enjoy

paragraphs.text:
If, after having tasted Dutch fare, you are hankering for some exoticism, you will enjoy this restaurant, which offers excellent Spanish cuisine. La Oliva, one of Amsterdam's most pleasing restaurants, is located in the heart of the trendy Jordaan neighbourhood. Candlelit tables create a warm atmosphere. Share a plate of "pintxos", tapas from the Basque region, as it is traditionally done. They are chef Alfredo Castillo Hoz's specialty and have ensured him a loyal following. Taste the fillet of monkfish with mushrooms sauce or the marinera clams, and rediscover some of the classics, like pata negra ham, tortillas and octopus salad with French dressing. Choose among the 35 Spanish wines on offer, served by the glass or bottle, to be enjoyed, of course, in moderation. If you feel like ending on a sweet note, try the Catalan cream, the chocolate mousse served with marinated strawberries or a surprising basil and mango panna cota…

La Oliva
Egelantiersstraat 122-124
1015 PR Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 320 4316

https://laoliva.nl/en/

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: Refined charm at Hotel Seven One Seven

introduction.small: It's like a family home… but better. You will be well taken care of in this boutique hotel of undeniable charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Refined charm at Hotel Seven One Seven

paragraphs.text:
You will feel at home in this charming four-star hotel, which opened in 1997. This is thanks to a courteous welcome, perfect service in all details, and the luxurious and comfortable decor. Right on the picturesque Prinsengracht canal close to the museums and the city centre the hotel is hidden away behind a discreet green door.

Seven One Seven is one of the most popular locations for tourists, due to its confidential aspect, so it's best to reserve very early if you would like the chance to spend a few days here especially since the hotel has only nine rooms, each with its own particular ambiance.

Each of these unique, tastefully decorated, and fairly large rooms is named after an artist: you can stay in the Picasso, Mahler, or even the Shakespeare room. It's your choice, given your personal artistic and literary preferences…

Hotel Seven One Seven
Prinsengracht 717
1017 JW Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 427 0717

https://717hotel.nl

Rooms: from 250 EUR

content.title: Hotel de l'Europe Amsterdam: the Heineken family's five-star hotel

introduction.small: With its stylish rooms, art collection, and attentive staff, this is truly a palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel de l'Europe Amsterdam: the Heineken family's five-star hotel

paragraphs.text:
Since opening in 1896, this is one of Amsterdam's most prestigious five-star locations. At Hotel de l'Europe, everything recalls a royal palace: vast halls, bathrooms of marble and mosaic tile, stylish furniture, attentive staff... Owned by the Heineken family, it has recently undergone renovation. Ideally situated in the historic heart of the city, it is nestled in a curve of the Amstel rive.

Rooms and suites are enhanced by a view over the river, as is the terrace, where a drink in good weather is truly a pleasure. If you're an art lover, you will enjoy the works of Dutch masters on display, including some from Alfred Heineken's personal collection. If you're a sporting enthusiast, do a few laps in the heated pool.

All visitors will enjoy an early evening in the luxury Spa before dining at one of the four restaurants, whose offerings rival each other in finesse and sophistication.

Hôtel de l'Europe
Nieuwe Doelenstraat 2-14
1012 CP Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 531 1777

https://www.deleurope.com

Rooms: from 360 EUR

content.title: Hotel Sofitel Legend the Grand Amsterdam: city hall turned hotel

introduction.small: Weddings were once celebrated in this former city hall. Now, it is a luxuriously renovated oasis of calm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Sofitel Legend the Grand Amsterdam: city hall turned hotel

paragraphs.text:
Memories of a historic past mingle with modern decor here. This former city hall on the bank of a charming little canal was where Queen Beatrix married Claus von Amsberg in 1966.

It is now a five-star establishment after having undergone more than two years of renovations under Sybille de Margerie in order to inject contemporary freshness to the 177 rooms and suites gentle tones of beige, violet, and off-white abound. Mahogany, marble, and steel clothe the large rooms of the building, which is accessed via a cobblestoned courtyard.

Enjoy the indoor garden resonating with birdsong, the library, and the superb spa. According to the Sofitel Hotels & Resorts chain (AccorHotels group), this is one of their most beautiful hotels, for which it deserves the title 'Legend.' At Bridges restaurant, you will enjoy the harmony of French and Dutch culinary traditions.

Hotel Sofitel Legend the Grand
Oudezijds Voorburgwal 197
1012 EX Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 555 3111

https://sofitel.accor.com/hotel/2783/index.en.shtml#origin=sofitel

Rooms: from 315 EUR

content.title: Blauw aan de Wal, Mediterranean-inspired cuisine

introduction.small: A shady courtyard, white tablecloths, and delicious meals: everything works in this restaurant's favour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Blauw aan de Wal, Mediterranean-inspired cuisine

paragraphs.text:
At the end of a tiny alley in a former warehouse is the Blauw aan de Wal restaurant. Stretched over three levels, it is a haven of calm in the heart of the Red Light District. Owner and chef Daan Olthuis favours seasonal produce and proposes Mediterranean-inspired cuisine: creamy octopus risotto, slices of roasted duck breast in marinated berries, wild sea bass filet and potato mash in sauce vierge, to name a few items.

The sober decor emphasises the bricks and beams of the original establishment and is completed by modern, refined furnishings. The tables are spaced sufficiently far apart for conversations to be private. On the ground level, the bar opens onto a shady private courtyard, which is lovely for dining, weather permitting.

Passing tourists as well as numerous locals have made this a favourite spot.

Blauw aan de Wal
Oudezijds Achterburgwal 99
1012 DD Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 330 2257

https://www.facebook.com/Blauw-aan-de-Wal-109130852495510/

Menu: around 62 EUR

content.title: Canal House: a sophisticated hotel for a demanding clientele

introduction.small: This hotel is built into old merchants' houses. The zest of history with contemporary decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Canal House: a sophisticated hotel for a demanding clientele

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the Jordaan residential neighbourhood, this boutique hotel is one of Amsterdam's most sophisticated. Built in three 17th-century merchants' houses along a canal near the arty district, the hotel still has its original fireplaces, beams, and mosaics, giving it a unique refinement. The 23 rooms, which are classed into six categories, are each different and well-sized. The walls are painted in deeper colours, which accentuate the hotel's intimate feel. White bedding is topped by a violet coverlet. Beautiful paintings complete the look. In some rooms, the bath area is separated by only a pane of glass. In the spring and summer, the garden, one of the largest in the city centre, is invaded by flowers. In this glamorous and contemporary space, you will feel at ease.

Canal House
Keizersgracht 148
1015 CX Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 622 5182

https://www.canalhouse.nl

Rooms: from 219 EUR

content.title: Conservatorium Hotel: Italian decoration and Dutch comfort

introduction.small: This hotel successfully blends Italian design, Dutch comfort, and an immense Spa for relaxation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Conservatorium Hotel: Italian decoration and Dutch comfort

paragraphs.text:
With its hundred-year old history, this former music academy in the museum district is now an affiliate of the Leading Hotels of the World chain, meaning luxury and sophistication, leading to multiple awards as best Dutch luxury hotel.

An immense atrium holds the reception area, bar, and dining room. Milanese interior architect Piero Lissoni has designed a minimalist yet comfortable contemporary atmosphere with Italian furniture, blonde parquet, and beige or grey tones in each room.

Allow yourself a moment to relax at the Akasha Holistic Wellbeing Centre, the largest Spa in the city, which offers the newest treatments available. A gym, sauna, and hammam are available. A swim in the magnificent swimming pool also helps to unwind after a day at the markets or hitting the shops.

Conservatorium Hotel
Van Baerlestraat 27
1071 AN Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 570 0000

https://www.conservatoriumhotel.com

Rooms: from 447 EUR

content.title: Warm up in a traditional “brown café”

introduction.small: Known for their nicotine-stained walls, “bruincafés” are an Amsterdam institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Warm up in a traditional “brown café”

paragraphs.text:
Never hesitate to take refuge in the cosy ambiance of one of these cafés, which are present on every corner of the city. Centuries of tobacco smoke have given a patina to the walls, the source of their name. Some have retained their traditional Oriental carpets, which have protected their tables for ages.

Most brown cafés are frequented by locals sharing a pint with friends after work. Foreigners are welcome, as the Dutch like to share their favourite spots, which become quite busy in the evenings, especially on Fridays and Saturdays. Drink beer on tap, coffee with a little bit of milk, or jenever, a Dutch spirit similar to gin, which is served very cold in tiny glasses and drunk in one go.

This drink is best accompanied by a sandwich or another dish otherwise, overindulgence can lead to a serious headache…

content.title: The Toren: uniquely colourful

introduction.small: Alongside a canal sits a uniquely colourful hotel: red, purple, black. Sophisticated but comfortable.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Toren: uniquely colourful

paragraphs.text:
Run by the Toren family for many years today (Eric and Petra are now at the helm), this boutique hotel sets itself apart by its unique style. This is the hotel for you if you appreciate the out-of-ordinary. Installed in two 17th-century houses next to the Keizersgracht canal, it boasts theatrical chic by a trendy Dutch designer.

In the 40 rooms, an original ambiance of red, purple, and black tones pair with golden details. Antique mirrors, chandeliers, and wall hangings add sophistication. Enjoy a beautiful view of the nearby canal from the rooms on the top floor. Some rooms can be arranged into a suite for those visiting with children. The generous breakfast is served in the bar under a ceiling painted by talented art students.

This hotel is extremely well situated, only a few steps away from the Anne Frank's House and a ten-minute walk from the Royal Palace.

The Toren
Keizersgracht 164
1015 CZ Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 622 6352

https://www.thetoren.nl

Rooms: from 138 EUR

content.title: The Dylan: stay in a palace

introduction.small: This little palace in a very elegant neighbourhood offers a very refined experience. Be spoiled by the personalised service.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Dylan: stay in a palace

paragraphs.text:
In the 18th century, Vivaldi, who was also a conductor, once gave a concert in this majestic house. Today, it is one of Amsterdam's most beautiful and elegant hotels. There are 40 rooms and suites, including duplexes with exposed beams. The decoration of the hotel's original owner, Anouska Hempel, has been preserved, with colours inspired by the Dutch East India Company. Renovated under the careful guidance of a new designer, the rooms are just as intimate and seductive, with their cream and white accents, black lacquer, exposed beams and Asian furnishings, all of which recall the former Dutch empire. The hotel offers its clients personalised services: as soon as you arrive, the concierges are ready with ideas and suggestions to make your stay as enjoyable as possible. The hotel is located in the elegant Nine Streets neighbourhood, where high-fashion boutiques abound, making it an ideal place to spend a few days of shopping and relaxation. Thanks to the talent of chef Dennis Kuiper, the hotel's restaurant, the Vinkeles, is considered one of the best in the city. Enjoy the view of the private gardens as you savour the crispy Anjou pigeon in foie gras sauce…

The Dylan
Keizersgracht 384
1016 GB Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 530 2010

https://www.dylanamsterdam.com

Rooms: from 350 EUR

content.title: Discover the Anne Frank House

introduction.small: Anne Frank wrote her famous diary while hidden in a little room of this house during the Nazi occupation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the Anne Frank House

paragraphs.text:
It is impossible to visit Anne Frank's house without a certain amount of emotion. Forced to live hidden with her family for two years, the young girl addressed her account of daily life between 1942 and 1944 to an imaginary friend: 'Today, I only have depressing news to announce,' she wrote in October 1942.

'Many of our Jewish friends are little by little being taken away by the Gestapo, which does not spare them.' This is what eventually happened to her family. Denounced, arrested, deported to the concentration camp of Bergen-Belsen, Anne Frank died of typhus at 15 years of age in March 1945. Only her father survived. Her diary was published several years later to worldwide acclaim.

Personal objects and extracts of her texts are exhibited here, bringing this tragic period to life. Don't hesitate to bring your children for an incredible history lesson.

Anne Frank House
Westermarkt 20
1016 DK Amsterdam

+31 (0)20 556 7105

https://www.annefrank.org/en

content.title: Envy: Italian gastronomy prepared before your eyes

introduction.small: You would almost believe you were in an Italian grocery. The beautiful decor is accompanied by excellent cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Envy: Italian gastronomy prepared before your eyes

paragraphs.text:
For several years now this very fashionable restaurant has been awarded a 'Bib Gourmand,' the Michelin guide's distinction awarded to potential starred restaurants. Creative cuisine, hip decor, beautiful plate presentation and muted atmosphere: Envy has many qualities. The dining room recalls an Italian grocery shop with its windowed refrigerators displaying a rich selection of cheeses and deli meats. Chef Floris prides himself on the fact that his cooks work under the eyes of the customers. He offers, among many other things, a subtle chorizo risotto with codium (pearl seaweed).
